question: Question_04_(b)
statement:
Let \emph{A} and \emph{B} be any two $\displaystyle n \times n$
matrices. Show that if $\displaystyle \lambda \neq 0$ is an eigenvalue
of AB and then $\displaystyle \lambda$ is also an eigenvalue of BA.
sols:
Let \emph{v} be an eigenvector of \emph{AB} with eigenvalue λ, \emph{ABv
= λv}. Using the vector $\displaystyle Bv$, we see that

$\displaystyle BA(Bv) = B((AB)v) = B(\lambda v) = \lambda Bv$

Hence by definition, $\displaystyle \lambda$ is an eigenvalue for
$\displaystyle BA$ (with eigenvector $\displaystyle Bv$).

(Alternatively, one can view the above proof as

\begin{align*}
ABv &= \lambda v  \\
B(ABv) &= B(\lambda v)  \\
BA(Bv) &= \lambda Bv  \\
\end{align*}

and then again we see that $\displaystyle \lambda$ is an eigenvalue for
matrix $\displaystyle BA$ associated to the vector $\displaystyle Bv$.
hints:
Let \emph{v} be the associated eigenvector of \emph{AB}. Use the vector
$\displaystyle Bv$.
